name: Renal - Functions/GFR
question1: Roles of the kidney : regulator(5), producer (4) and excreter (2)
contents:
• To regulate
  • (1) Extracellular fluid volume
  • (2) Extracellular fluid electrolyte composition
  • (3) Total body water volume
  • (4) The body’s acid-base balance
  • (5) Arterial blood pressure
  • Producer:
  • (1) EPO :
  • fall in O2 level in renal tissues --> Erythropoietin secretion by peritubular cells in kidney. stimulates RBC precursors in bone marrow and their differentiation to RBC's.
  • (2) Vitamin D: Active form
  • KIDNEY: converted to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol
  • Raises serum Ca2+ by:
  • Promoting GI absorption
  • Decreasing renal excretion (increased tubular reabsorption)
  • Stimulating bone reabsorption
  • (3) Renin
  • (4) Glucose
  • Excreter
  • Endogenous waste products; for example, urea, creatinine, uric acid, and bilirubin
  • Exogenous waste products; for example, drugs and drug metabolites
question2: What is Glomerular filtration rate? Define Filtration fraction.  What are Starling forces across the glomerular capillary membrane?
contents2:
• Anatomy of Glomerulus
  • Podocytes covering the ball of glomerular capillaries have filtration channels of ~ 30 nm diameter, negatively charged
  • Cut-off - Mol Wt < 55,000-60,000 (8 nm)
  • Anions pass less easily than cations or uncharged particles
  • GFR
  • Glomerular filtration rate measures the rate at which blood is filtered by the kidneys
  • Glomerular filtration rate is a unit of measure of kidney excretory function
  • GFR - it is usually expressed as ml/min and is approximately 125 ml/min or 180L/day
  • values in women are 10% lower than those in men.
  • 1.5 kg NaCl/day!
  • Define Filtration fraction
  • This is the ratio of GFR to RPF (~0.16-0.2)
  • Filtration Fraction (working out)
  • Renal blood flow = 1.2 L/min (20-25% of cardiac output)
  • Renal plasma flow = 720 mL/min (haematocrit 40%)
  • Glomerular FR = 120 mL/min
  • while the remainder continues into the efferent arterioles.
  • Filtration fraction = 120 / 720 = 0.17
  • Normal range 0.15 – 0.2
  • Can be increased to maintain GFR if renal blood flow
  • Urine output 100ml/hr (1.5mls/min) - most then is re-absorbed.




The diagram above illustrates Starlings forces in the renal vascular bed.

The diagram illustrates the forces at play in the following equation:

  • As can be seen (if we take oncotic pressure at Bowmans capsule to be around 0 - because only v.small amounts of protein enter Bowmans capsule.


  • GFR = Kf [(Pgc - Pb) - (πgc)]
  • Pgc - hydrostatic pressure in Glomerular capillary = 45 (constant)
  • Pb - hydrostatic pressure in Bowmans capsule = 10 (constant)
  • πgc - starts at around 25mmHg - but increases as filtration occurs - plasma proteins become concentrated to 35mmHg at the end.
  • So Net ultra-filtration pressure starts at 10mmHg and then decreases to 0mmHg by the end of the capillaries.
  • Just proximal to the efferent arteriole, the net ultrafiltration pressure is reduced to zero and filtration ceases***


Pgc is higher (45mmHg) than in other capillary beds (32mmHg) because:

  • Afferent arterioles are short and straight
  • Efferent arterioles have relatively high resistance

Pgc favours filtration and is opposed by :

  • Hydrostatic pressure in Bowmans capsule
  • Osmotic pressure gradient across the glomerular capillaries
contents3:
GFR can either be:

  • (1) estimated using predication formulae ( based on factors such as patients age, sex and serum creatinine) or
  • (2) calculated (using the plasma clearance of a suitable substance by applying the FICK principle)
  • Estimated GFR:
  • Most commonly used formulae is the Cockcroft-Gault (C&G) equation and the Modification of Diet in Renal Disease study [MDRD].
  • C&G is inaccuate in overweight individuals and in fluid overload
  • Calculated using the Fick principle:
  • Clearance (GFR) = Urine concentration x Urine flow / Plasma concentration

(see also Renal flow for its derivation - with respect to renal flow)
question4: How and why is inulin used to asses renal function?
contents4:
(see also Renal blood flow - for same argument)

Inulin - is an exogenous polysaccharide with a molecular weight of 5200 Daltons, meets all the criteria of an ideal substance as follows:


  • Freely filtered through the glomeruli (not bound to protein)
  • Not reabsorbed nor secreted
  • Not metabolised
  • Not stored in the kidney
  • No effect on the filtration rate
  • Not toxic
  • Easy to measure in plasma and urine
